Problem:
Consider a mathematical scenario where a signal x(t) undergoes a Fourier Transform, defined as \\(\\hat{x}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} x(t) e^{-i \\omega t} dt\\). Further, this transformed signal is modified via a filter function H(ω), and the composite effect \\(y(t)\\) is obtained by applying the Inverse Fourier Transform to \\(H(\\omega) \\hat{x}(\\omega)\\).

If the signal x(t) is input without any modifications and H(ω) is a linear time-invariant (LTI) system, does y(t) depend solely on the properties of H(ω) and x(t)?
Explanation: Since H(ω) is linear and time-invariant, the output y(t) will be the convolution of x(t) with the impulse response of H(ω), making it depend only on x(t) and the properties of H(ω), assuming no additional intervention.
